clinical_study.brief_title: Significance of Early Mobilization After VATS-L
clinical_study.official_title: Physiological Evidence for Early Mobilization in Thoracoscopic Lobectomy

brief_summary.textblock:
The main endpoint is physiological rehabilitation after VATS-L under early mobilization. The secondary endpoints are exploring the effect of early mobilization on postoperative physiology.
Investigators hypothesis that early mobilization is clearly advantaged to advance the physiological recovery.

primary_outcome.measure: Postoperative forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 3 days
primary_outcome.description: FEV1 is the amount of air you can force from your lungs in one second. Participants will be examed via spirometer.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 3 days
primary_outcome.description: Oxygen saturation is the fraction of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin relative to total hemoglobin (unsaturated + saturated) in the blood. Participants will be tested via oximeter.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 3 days
Through study completion, an average of 3 days
secondary_outcome.description: The numeric rating scale (NRS) ranging from 0 (no pain) to 10 (excruciating pain) is used to score postoperative pain.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 3 days
Through study completion, an average of 2 days

secondary_outcome.description: Pneumothorax, subcutaneous emphysema, pneumonia, empyema, bleeding, pulmonary embolism, prolong air leakage, re-intervention, re-surgery and re-admission will be recording specifically.

intervention.description: Mobilization as soon as patients can, which is not limited on walking
